awd_titl_txt: REU SITE: Research Experiences for Undergraduates in Software Systems and Analysis
awd_abstract_narration:
This project sets up an REU site focused on software systems and analysis at Texas State University. This REU site provides opportunities for a cohort of undergraduate students to participate in research and development of innovative software systems and analysis technologies that would have enormous public benefits. The site emphasizes the participation of a diverse group of students, in particular, women, minorities, first generation, and non-traditional students. The project includes workshops, entrepreneurship forum, student presentations and posters, field trips and other professional development opportunities. The goal is to increase retention of computer science students, instill in them the spirit of innovation, improve their career perspectives, engage them to participate in cutting-edge research in software systems and analysis, and motivate them to enter graduate computer science programs.

Software affects nearly every aspect of our lives and holds the key to many scientific and engineering challenges. As software is increasingly pervasive nowadays, software-related problems have become much more prevalent. This project will study new trends in software systems including mobile software systems, green computing, internet of things, big data and parallel systems while analyzing various software qualities such as reliability, performance, usability, safety, maintainability, and energy efficiency.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SITE-Res Exp for Ugrd Site

por.por_cntn:
The primary objective of REUSSA (CCF-1659807) is to motivate a diverse body of undergraduate students (female, minority, non-traditional, first-generation college students) in the exploration of research processes in computer science and to inspire them to undertake graduate studies in computer science and/or careers in the IT field. The main research theme covered in the 10-week summer program is on Software System and Analysis . The site official web site can be found in http://reussa.cs.txstate.edu

REUISSA supported 40 student participants, which was ten over the original budgeted.  The two years no cost extension supported additional ten students. Among the participants, 27 were males, 13 were females, 4 were non-traditional students, 7 were Hispanics or African Americans, and 8 were first generation college students. Overall, more than 50% of the students were from the diverse group that we are targeting. Four students have started their graduate schools. The rest of the students are all currently working in various IT industries ranging from government labs to big tech firm like Microsoft and Google. The following is the list of papers published with REUSSA students as co-authors:

1.     Ngu. AHH. , Eyitayo J., Yang G., Campbell C., Sheng QZ. Ni J. (2021). ?An IoT Edge Computing Framework using Cordova Accessor Host?. IEEE Internet of Things Journal, April, 2021

2.     Tarek Mahmud and Mujahid Khan and Jihan Rouijel and Meiru Che and Guowei Yang, API Change Impact Analysis for Android Apps, 45th IEEE Computers, Software, and Applications Conference (COMPSAC), July, 2021.

3.     Ngu, AHH., Coyne S., Srinivas P., Metsis, V.,? Collaborative Edge-Cloud Computing for Personalized Fall Detection?. 17th IFIP  WG 12.5 International Conference on  Artificial Intelligent Applications and Innovations, , AIAI 2021: 323-336, Greece, June 25-27

4.     Jacob M. Hope, Mikel Gjergji, Johana Di Girolamo, Marco A. Alvarez, and Apan Qasem. Characterizing Input-Sensitivity in Tightly-Coupled Collaborative Graph Algorithms. 21st IEEE/ACM International Symposium on Cluster, Cloud and Internet Computing (CCGrid21), Melbourne, Australia, May 10-13, 2021, pages 287-296. IEEE, 2021. doi: 10.1109/CCGrid51090.2021.00038.  [Best Paper Award].

5.     Johana Di Girolamo, Jacob M. Hope, and Apan Qasem. Uncovering Input-Sensitive Energy Bottlenecks in Oversubscribed GPU Workloads. Journal of Sustainable Computing: Informatics and Systems (SUSCOM), 2021 (To Appear)

6.     Samimi, Hanie and Mehta, Isha and Docking, Thomas Roderick and Zainulabadeen, Aamir and Karsan, Aly and Zare, Habil, DNA methylation analysis improves the prognostication of acute myeloid leukemia, ejHaem, 2(2), 211-218, https://doi.org/10.1002/jha2.187

7.     Mauldin, T., Ngu, AHH, Metsis, V., Canby, M. (2020). Ensemble Deep Learning on Wearables Using Small Datasets. ACM Transactions on Computing for Healthcare,Vol. 2, No. 1,  December, 2020

8.     Mauldin, T., Ngu, AHH, Metsis, V., Canby, M.,Tesic, J.,  (2019). Experimentation and Analysis of Ensemble Deep Learning in IoT Applications. Open Journal of Internet Of Things (OJIOT), 5(1), 133?149. Retrieved from https://www.ronpub.com/ojiot/OJIOT_2019v5i1n11_Mauldin.html

 

9.  Jacob Hope, Trisha Nag, and Apan Qasem. Energy-efficient gpu graph processing with on-demand page migration. In Tenth International Green and Sustainable Conference (IGSC19), Oct 2019

 

10.  Ngu, A., Metsis, V., Coyne S., Chung, B., Pai, R., & Chang, J. (2020). Personalized Fall Detection System. In the proceedings of the 5th IEEE PerCom Workshop on Pervasive Health Technologies, Austin, Texas, March. 2020.

 

11.  Taylor R. Mauldin, Marc E. Canby, Vangelis Metsis, Anne H. Ngu and  Coralys Cubero, ?SmartFall: A Smartwatch-based Fall Detection System Using Deep Learning?,  Sensors, Vol. 18, No. 10, ISSN:1424-8220, Article number:3363, 2018.

 

12.  Ngu, AHH, Tseng, P.-T., Paliwal, M., Carpenter, C., & Stipe, W. (2018). Smartwatch-Based IoT Fall Detection Application. Open Journal of Internet Of Things (OJIOT), 4(1), 87?98. Retrieved from http://nbn-resolving.de/urn:nbn:de:101:1-2018080519304951282148

13.  Guowei Yang, Jeffrey Jones, Austin Moninger and Meiru Che, ?How Do Android Operating System Updates Impact Apps?? IEEE/ACM International Conference on Mobile Software Engineering and Systems (MOBILESoft 2018), Gothenburg, Sweden, May 2018.

14.  Zainulabadeen, Aamir, Philip Yao, and Habil Zare. "Underexpression of Specific Interferon Genes Is Associated with Poor Prognosis of    Melanoma." PloS one 12.1 (2017): e0170025. January 23, 2017. https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pone.0170025

 

The following data set was made available to the public as a result of REUSSA:

  • Fall data set from 14 healthy adults http://cs.txstate.edu/~hn12/data/SmartFallDataSet.zip. This dataset has been cited 70 times since publication in 2018.
  • GPU Graph Analytic dataset (http://www.graphml.info)
  • A 360 Egocentric Kinetic Human Activity Video Dataset (https://egok360.github.io/)
  • Android App Mobile testing and analysis dataset (https://userweb.cs.txstate.edu/~t_m386/apicia.html)

 

The program had trained undergraduate students and two graduate students in:

1.     Advanced technology development

2.     Background materials on IoT, machine learning, data mining, R, Mathlab and Weka.

3.     Research processes and research ethics

4.     Research presentation and writing skills

5.     Poster preparation and what to expect during the poster judging session

6.     Applying to graduate schools and applying for NSF Graduate Fellowship

7.     Life as a researcher or an IT worker via industry visits

8.     Transitioning from college to IT career

 

 


Last Modified: 03/02/2022
Modified by: Anne H Ngu
